\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document} $$ {p}_R=\sqrt{\left({\mu}_1^2+{\mu}_2^2+\dots \dots \dots +{\mu}_{20}^2\right)} $$ \end{document}
p R

μ 1 2

μ 20 2
Identical protein sequences have the same p
R values, which change with any alteration in the amino acid composition and distribution in the sequence. Δ p
R is used to compare the differences between two protein sequences quantitatively as the Euclidean distance between two protein graph radii:
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document} $$ \Delta {p}_R=\sqrt{\left\{{\left({\mu}_1-{\mu}_1^{\prime}\right)}^2+{\left({\mu}_2-{\mu}_2^{\prime}\right)}^2+\dots \dots \dots {\left({\mu}_{20}-{\mu}_{20}^{\prime}\right)}^2\right\}} $$ \end{document}
Δ
p R
=

−
